## Steps to reproduce

Go to any linux CI build and look for artifacts
Go to the home page of the project and look at the link to get the build
## Expected behavior

There should be a link to get the latest passed CI build from the development branch (currently master)
## Actual behavior

The link to get the build is a fixed release (which is needed, but something different)

## Steps to reproduce
- Open new terminal on Linux
- run `powershell`
- `import-module ./build.psm1 -Force`
- Start-PSxUnit -Verbose 

Note: same could be applicable to other functions from `build.psm1`
## Expected behavior

test run
## Actual behavior

error that `dotnet` is unknown command
## Environment data

<!-- If running the latest released version, specify the version, i.e. -->

v0.4.0

<!-- If running you own build, please fill in the results of the following commands: -->

``` powershell
> $PSVersionTable

```

``` sh
$ dotnet --info

That's the thing. dotnet is not there by default :)

$ git rev-parse HEAD; git status

58425bbcc0c7f5845d0b9230b1dceb7d24cceb03
```

labels.description: specific to affecting the build
labels.name: Area-Maintainers-Build

title: All functions that uses dotnet should setup env PATH

body:
There are few people, who are working simultaneously on adding new dlls to the build.

Current [mapping](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/master/docs/workflow/mapping.md) process is not suitable for that case: it uses single `mappings.json` file which makes it hard to isolate porting new assemlbies.
### Proposed changes
- Split `mappings.json` into `mappings.json` for every project (folder under `src`)
- Throw away `src\monad` prefix, now it's not relevant
- Make `Copy-SubmoduleFiles` flexible about set of `mappings.json` that it uses
- Add checks to `Copy-SubmoduleFiles` to avoid copying wrong versions of files.

labels.description: specific to affecting the build
labels.name: Area-Maintainers-Build

title: Enhancements for files mapping

## Actual behavior

<!--

If you are running a released version of powershell, but not the latest one, install the latest from https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/releases and try to repro it again

Before submitting this issue, please first:

- [ ] Search the existing issues.
- [ ] Refer to the [FAQ](../docs/FAQ.md).
- [ ] Refer to the [known issues](../docs/KNOWNISSUES.md).
- [ ] If it is a bug, fill out this form:
-->
## Steps to reproduce
- From windows box, open inbox powershell
- ssh to a linux VM. Use ssh that comes with windows version of git from command line

```
C:\Program Files\Git\usr\bin\ssh.exe
```
- Follow [instructions](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/master/docs/building/linux.md#toolchain-setup) to install powershell
- Everything works fine up to this point
- Run powershell
- Try to do something
## Expected behavior

You should be able to work
## Actual behavior

Console UX is broken:
half of commands are entered at the top of the screen, overriding the buffer

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/816680/15945104/96e1e294-2e45-11e6-8f91-a2c59efa13e0.png)
## Environment data

<!-- If running the latest released version, specify the version, i.e. -->

v0.4.0

body:
Since it's very typical for distributions to provide the source code in src rpm format (for rpm based) distributions and also all its dependencies so that you can do rpmbuild of the .src.rpm to generate the .rpm. That will be a requirement if we ever want to see powershell be distributed by the likes of centos,fedora, (also rhel) since the build system and all is based on a build rpm from src to rpm.

so this means that we have to start with the dot net rpm, have src rpms for dot net and also powershell.

has anyone been looking into this at all?

labels.description: the issue is more of a feature request than a bug
labels.name: Issue-Enhancement

labels.description: specific to affecting the build
labels.name: Area-Maintainers-Build

body: I, like many *nix folks, am used to typing ctrl-d to exit my shell. Most if not all linux commandline tools that have a ‘shell’ support control-d out of it. Whether it’s screen, bash, an ssh session, mail, cat I want to leave.
title: Support for ctrl-d to exit powershell

body:
This ports the `Trace-Command`, `Get-TraceSource`, and `Set-TraceSource` cmdlets from `Microsoft.PowerShell.Commands.Utility`.

This enables the use of PowerShell tracing, e.g. `Trace-Command -Expression { Get-ChildItem } -Name PathResolution -PSHost` for PowerShell Core.

/cc @lzybkr @adityapatwardhan @JamesWTruher 

@daxian-dbw where .NET Core APIs have changed, (specifically the lack of `Close()` methods), are the changes I made correct (use `Dispose()` instead) or is there something else we should do here?
title: Port Trace-Command

``` sh
PS /workspace/PowerShell> function my-alias {
$p = $args[0]
get-alias | where {$_.definition -like "*$p"} | ft definition, name -auto
}
PS /workspace/PowerShell> set-psbreakpoint -command my-alias

Entering debug mode. Use h or ? for help.                                                                                                                       Hit Command breakpoint on 'my-alias'

At line:1 char:19
+ function my-alias {
+                   ~
```

body:
Importing `build.psm1` now warns:

> WARNING: The names of some imported commands from the module 'build' include unapproved verbs that might make them less discoverable. To find the commands with unapproved verbs, run the Import-Module command again with the Verbose parameter. For a list of approved verbs, type Get-Verb.

This is due to `Create` not being an approved verb.

I think `New` would be appropriate:

``` powershell
> Get-Verb | Select-String new                                                                                                            

@{Verb=New; Group=Common}
```

body:
## Steps to reproduce

```
add-type -typedefinition "public class foo { public int x;}"
add-type -typedefinition "public class foo { public int x;}"
add-type -typedefinition "public class foo { public int x;}"
[foo]
```
## Expected behavior

```
IsPublic IsSerial Name                                     BaseType
-------- -------- ----                                     --------
True     False    foo                                      System.Object
```
## Actual behavior

```
Type name 'foo' is ambiguous, it could be 'foo, 4x0tnmyc.wol, Version=0.0.0.0, Culture=neutral,
PublicKeyToken=null' or 'foo, jzx4booc.2db, Version=0.0.0.0, Culture=neutral, PublicKeyToken=null'.
At line:1 char:1
+ [foo]
+ ~~~~~
    + CategoryInfo          : InvalidArgument: (:) [], RuntimeException
    + FullyQualifiedErrorId : AmbiguousTypeReference
```

title: Build pwrshsip.dll for Windows PowerShell

body:
Assume that I have written a script which is a paragon of portability. It runs on all the platforms without modification, and is in my PATH. On Windows, I type:
`PS> Hello`
and it executes!

should I be able to do the same on non-windows platforms? Note that I have not typed the actual name of the file on Windows (which is `hello.ps1`), just `hello`.

`#!powershell` does not address this issue, because it doesn't change the name of the script. Are we going to suggest that our users create 2 copies of the same file:
`hello` and `hello.ps1`
one for Windows, another for not?
are we going to require our users to type `hello.ps1` on non-Windows platforms?

I suggest that we support our current behavior on non-Windows platforms, we supply the `.ps1`, and use the same disambiguation logic that we do for  `.cmd`, `.exe`, etc, which an additional ` ` which is no extension. This way if files (on non-windows)

```
hello
hello.ps1
```

we would execute `hello`.  _similar to what we would do if we found_ `hello.exe` _on windows_
If we find only `hello.ps1`, and the user types `hello`, we run it and not require the user to type the actual filename

labels.description: (LEGACY) Helps filter issues that might be higher priority because they directly affect usability
labels.name: Usability

title: Should non-windows system users be required to include the extension when executing scripts?

body:
In other words, port [this](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/d811fe37ea376fead1f62c2c1de01dc2f0689f7f/src/Microsoft.PowerShell.ConsoleHost/host/msh/ConsoleHost.cs#L334) to work on Linux.

This is not an event we'll receive from `System.Console` (all signals received by the event handler are handled in #1039), but we should catch `SIGTERM` and call `SpinUpBreakHandlerThread(true)`.

/cc @lzybkr

body:
Currently, launching `powershell` shows a product name and copyright notice:

```
Windows PowerShell
Copyright (C) 2016 Microsoft Corporation. All rights reserved.
```

At the very least, we should change `Windows PowerShell` to `PowerShell`, and we should look into whether we can remove the Copyright notice with LCA as well. 

If there are any other instances of "Windows PowerShell" branding throughout the project, we should remove those as well before launch.

This will be a list of all PowerShell assemblies, checked indicates it is built for PowerShell repo:
- [x] `Microsoft.PowerShell.Commands.Management`
- [x] `Microsoft.PowerShell.Commands.Utility`
- [x] `Microsoft.PowerShell.ConsoleHost`
- [x] `Microsoft.PowerShell.CoreCLR.AssemblyLoadContext`
- [x] `Microsoft.PowerShell.CoreCLR.Eventing`
- [x] `Microsoft.PowerShell.PSReadLine`
- [x] `Microsoft.PowerShell.Security`
- [x] `System.Management.Automation`

body:
```powershell
function Get-CronJob {
<#
.SYNOPSIS
  Returns the current cron jobs from the cron table
.DESCRIPTION
  Returns the current cron jobs from the cron table
.EXAMPLE
  Get-CronJob -UserName Steve
.RETURNVALUE
  CronJob objects
.PARAMETER UserName
  Optional parameter to specify a specific user's cron table
#>

[CmdletBinding()]
[OutputType([PSObject])]
param (
    [Alias("u")][Parameter(Mandatory=$false)][String] $UserName
)
process {
    $crontab = Get-CronTab -user $UserName
    ForEach ($line in $crontab) {
        if ($line.Trim().Length -gt 0)
        {
            ConvertTo-CronJob -crontab $line
        }
    }
}

}
```

Get-CronJob -?
## Expected behavior

help text
## Actual behavior

syntax only
## Environment data

v0.4.0

body:
We need tests for PowerShell, and then to fix the cmdlets.

<!--

If you are running a released version of powershell, but not the latest one, install the latest from https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/releases and try to repro it again

Before submitting this issue, please first:

- [ ] Search the existing issues.
- [ ] Refer to the [FAQ](../docs/FAQ.md).
- [ ] Refer to the [known issues](../docs/KNOWNISSUES.md).
- [ ] If it is a bug, fill out this form:
-->
## Steps to reproduce

``` powershell
~ |-/ Start-Job -ScriptBlock { get-process }

Id     Name            PSJobTypeName   State         HasMoreData     Location             Command
--     ----            -------------   -----         -----------     --------             -------
1      Job1            BackgroundJob   Failed        False           localhost             get-process


~ |-/ Get-Job

Id     Name            PSJobTypeName   State         HasMoreData     Location             Command
--     ----            -------------   -----         -----------     --------             -------
1      Job1            BackgroundJob   Failed        False           localhost             get-process


~ |-/ Receive-Job Job1
An error has occurred which Windows PowerShell cannot handle. A remote session might have ended.
    + CategoryInfo          : OpenError: (localhost:String) [], PSRemotingDataStructureException
    + FullyQualifiedErrorId : PSSessionStateBroken

```
## Expected behavior

@BrucePay can you fill this in?
## Actual behavior

See above.
## Environment data

v0.4.0

body: This resolves #1004 and will use the latest released asset in the future. The download script is as complicated as it is because this is a private repo, thus access to the assets must be done through the API with authentication. This all can go away when we go public. I'm not a big fan of the Perl usage, but `grep -oP` is not available on OS X. @JamesWTruher is probably about to come up with a much better Perl expression :ocean: /cc @vors --- This change is [](https://reviewable.io/reviews/powershell/powershell/1008)

body: This resolves #560 with a regression test. Please note that this test is _slow_, taking ~7 [seconds](https://travis-ci.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/jobs/40420622#L904). @JamesWTruher I investigated speeding this by using a thread with a much smaller stack size, but the needed constructor is not available in [.NET Core](https://github.com/dotnet/corefx/blob/master/src/System.Threading.Thread/ref/System.Threading.Thread.cs). Perhaps we need to start separating unit tests from _slow_ regression etc. tests. --- This change is [](https://reviewable.io/reviews/powershell/powershell/1007)
